Award.AwardTitle: Physical and Chemical Directors of Molecular Asymmetry in Lipid Bilayers
Award.AbstractNarration: The Analytical and Surface Chemistry (ASC) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. John Conboy of the University of Utah. Prof. Conboy and his students will study the origin of phospholipid asymmetry in simple model membrane systems. Compositional asymmetry in the lipid membrane is thought to play a crucial role in membrane structural stability, intercellular signaling, and the organization of membrane-associated components. Prof. Conboy and his students will use sum frequency vibrational spectroscopy (SFVS) to directly measure the trans bilayer movement of phospholipids and asymmetry in a variety of membrane models to determine the rate of exchange of native phospholipids. SFVS will also be used to measure membrane asymmetry, kinetics of transmembrane migration, and thermodynamic analysis of the transition state barrier to migration. Success of the proposed studies will have wide-reaching implications in molecular and cellular biology. The study will provide excellent educational training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral trainees in a highly multidisciplinary research area involving the development and application of state of the art no-linear spectroscopic methods in complex biological systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All life as we know it is cellular in nature.  One of the crucial components of cells is the membrane which separates a cell from its environment.  A cell membranes is composed of a variety of components (proteins, carbohydrates, cholesterol) supported in a lipid matrix only two molecules thick, (Figure 1). All lipids share the same basic structure: a polar headgroup and a fatty, non-polar tail. This physical structure of a lipid allows them to organize spontaneously into the characteristic two layer or “bilayer” structure where the polar headgroups point outward and the fatty tails point inward to form a non-polar core.

 The specific location (inside versus outside layer) of a lipid in a cell membrane plays a direct role in the function and health of cells. Specifically, it is known that cellular membranes contain a nonrandom and unequal distribution of various lipid types between the two layers of the membrane. The asymmetric distribution of this lipid in the membrane has been linked to  a myriad of diseases, including Alzheimer’s, Tangier’s disease, and Scott syndrome.

 Despite our growing knowledge about where and why lipids are distributed within a cell membrane, there is a lack of information about how lipids are arranged in a specific distribution. A fundamental understanding of lipid behavior is required to fully understand lipid asymmetry. The research funded by this NSF grant directly investigated native lipid behavior as well as biological interactions that may contribute lipid asymmetry within a cell membrane.

 Our research efforts have been focused on the lateral movement of lipids from one layer of the membrane to the other, called lipid flip-flop (Figure 1). We investigated how lipid structure impacts the speed and energy requirements of native lipid flip-flop by varying the length of the non-polar tails and the polarity of the headgroup. These studies showed that flip-flop became faster when the tails are shorter or the headgroup was less polar. The polarity of the headgroup had a much more significant effect, indicating that the main energy barrier for flip-flop is the headgroup entering the non-polar core. Additionally, these studies indicate that native lipid flip-flop in biological membranes will occur on the order of seconds: an order of magnitude faster than previously reported.

 The understanding of how lipids move in the absence of external forces provided a baseline to extract the impact of specific biological interactions that occur in membranes. The first of these external forces examined was membrane-spanning proteins. Because biological proteins are typically quite large and complex, we imitated just the membrane-spanning portion by incorporating small peptides across the membrane (Figure 2). This work found that if the peptide has some polar areas, flip-flop becomes much faster. The polar sections of the protein lower the energy required for the polar headgroup to enter and cross the non-polar core.

 Having a much better understanding of how lipids move across a membrane, we next investigated how lateral asymmetry is created in a cell membrane. This is a vital component of cell function and involves stopping flip-flop of certain lipids. We were particularly interested in lipids with a negatively charged headgroup as defects in their lateral asymmetry are strongly implicated in diseases. In this study, we mimicked the inside of a cell by introducing a solution of positively charged molecules over a membrane containing these negative lipids (Figure 2). The attraction between the opposite charges prevented the lipids from undergoing flip-flop to create a high degree of lateral asymmetry.
